properties.media:imagetext:
Sunday
January 8, 1950
Dear Family,
We left Paris by logon Lits Friday night, arriving Brussels
early Saturday morning.
Took off in a Constellation with thirty-five
of its forty-one seats
filled at 5:00 pm,
flew down the Rhone Valley
to Marseilles,
across Corsica to Rome - Naples - Athens, across Cyprus,
over Beirut and after a nine hour flight arrived
at Damascus at 2:00
a.m.
this morning.
One of the drawbacks to my
travel in the past has been the
fact that I never quite enjoy any experience because I always
wish
SO
much that the family were along to enjoy it too.
Well, this time they
are - or at least the one most important member and ith of the
others -
or I should say 1/7th because the two Bills and Sam Ere included.
We thought Damascus would not be crowded but it was.
we had to sit up until 5:00 a.m.
crawl into beds newly made up
after a plane departure at
that hour.
until about 10:00 a.m.,
had breakfast in our room not rooms - because Hebe was quartered with
and then went out on the town with an English-speaking guide
Abraham Baho, a Syrian Christian.
(When Hebe had trouble pronouncing
his last name he said,
"Just call me 'Abraham'.") Debby and Hebe were
enthusiastic over the native city - the Bazzar with its wonderful
shops and the second largest mosque in the world - the old church
John the Baptist.
We saw the over-sized tomb which
the head of John the Baptist,
we also saw the tomb of
Saladin.
Then we went all through the
ex-sultan's palace and
saw the quarters
where his thirty-five wives lived.
Our guide told us
several times
that the wives were never permitted to leave
the palace,
but to me
that repetition was unnecessery.
If those thirty-five wives had got
loose in those shops in the Bazzar the sultan would probably have become
a priest after the bankruptcy
proceedings!
After a drive down the
Street
called Straight we had
lunch - very
good - then drove about
twenty-five miles out along the excellent highway which runs to
Bagdad,
turned off to a little mountain town called Malulah where
there is a small
community
the members of which - some five hundred
strong
still speak the language of Christ.
For over 2,000 years
they have lived at the end of a fertile
valley with their village at
the sheltered end
and their Roman Catholic monastery high above on
the mountainside.
We reached the church by walking up & narrow gorge
cut in the massive rocks by a mountain stream which was still there.
Along the
trail
there were numerous caves, hollowed
out of the solid
rock back in
the days when the Romans were there.
At the top,
the
Shangri-la like monastery wes surrounded by hills many oi which were
snowce pped.
Bishop - as fine a
looking character as you ever
saw - had us served with twenty year old
wine and gave us some unleavened bread and
cheese - all very good
indeed, especially the wine.
The latter is made on the place from
their
own vineyards.
